p: Gallic acid is present in fruits and vegetables [ 66]; gallnuts, grapes, and blackberries [ 67]; eucalyptus species and Picea schrenkiana [ 68]; tea [ 69]; chestnuts and several berries [ 51]; Myriophyllum spicatum, Cynomorium coccineum, and Microcystis aeruginosa [ 70, 71]; and black tea [ 72]. It has many medicinal uses such as antimicrobial [ 73], neuroprotection [ 74], antioxidant [ 75, 76], anticancer [ 77, 78], and antiulcer [ 79] uses and for cardiovascular diseases (CVDs) [ 80]. Furthermore, gallic acid has lipid homeostasis [ 81] and antihyperglycemic effects [ 82] and acts as a cardioprotective agent [ 83, 84]. Gallic acid is also used in the food industry; in manufacturing inks, paints, and dyes; and in cinematography [ 85]. Gallic acid has been identified in various plants, and its allelopathic potential has also been shown in many studies [ 86, 87, 88, 89], but this is the first report on gallic acid in Wedelia chinensis so far.
